Definition: Toxicity is defined as something that makes someone want to quit a conversation because it is harsh, insulting, or unfair. You must sort the input statement into one of two categories: Toxic and Non-toxic.

Positive Examples.input:
Comment: Although it is not true that all conservatives are stupid people, it is true that most stupid people are conservative.

 John Stuart Mill
Positive Examples.explanation: This is a toxic comment because it is disrespectful.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Why? You just wasted  5 minutes of my life.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is a non-toxic comment because it is not rude or desrespectful.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: I personally know and work with Muslims. None of them cover their faces.
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be non-toxic because the comment only speaks about muslims but does not disrespect them.

Negative Examples.explanation: This should be toxic because it disrespects Glen.

1650s, from Greek oxymoron, noun use of neuter of oxymoros (adj.) "pointedly foolish," from oxys "sharp" (see acrid) + moros "stupid" (see moron). Comment: As an erstwhile writer, I cannot but agree with the author.

The 'cultural appropriation' crowd would have us all sequestered into our own little boxes, labeled with our sexuality, labeled with our racial background, labeled with our sex, and from that box we are graciously 'allowed' to write. Screw empathy. Screw exploration of concepts or cultures. Screw curiosity or, gasp, failure. The concept that we're all trying to transcend those all-too-limited labels seems to be lost on them.

If I write a novel with an indigenous character and I don't do the character justice, the proper solution is to educate me, show me where I went wrong, illustrate how my characterization could have been more accurate, give me better descriptions of native concepts or a clearer picture into their world.

But to tell me I can't write that character in the first place?  How small minded.  How petty. How controlling.

Comment: I, too, have a dash-cam installed, front AND rear-facing.  It's already paid for itself from claims that something was my fault, when it wasn't. I've even switched insurance carriers when they wouldn't agree my video evidence was enough.  Fortunately, the courts agreed with me.
An interesting outcome, is that I think I am driving more carefully WITH the dash-cam.  So it's a win-win for everyone.  Except the ones who get caught being stupid......

Comment: 1. You're an idiot. I said nothing about medical care, and I wasn't talking about hunter/gatherers. It is a FACT that the first plastered walls were built by the SAME early farmers who also built the first grain stores. Agriculture allowed, for the first time, overproduction of food - so working for a few months a year would provide food for the rest of the year. Plaster was a major thing - it has ZERO survival value. It takes days of backbreaking labour, maintaining a fire at very high heat constantly - for no reward other than aesthetics. It's something that would never have happened in a society without an abundance of leisure time. And it's important that it did - the same fire-handling techniques they developed to make their walls smooth - was what allowed their grandchildren to smelt ore and end the stone age.

Comment: I see this assertion a lot, but have never read why some people believe it to be indisputable truth.  It is not.

"As humans, we also need rituals"

SOME people may DESIRE to particiopate in rituals, but to say that ALL people "need" rituals is not true.  

In the context of religion, some desire some rituals in certain contexts (they don't "need" ritual), others pretty much forgo ritual (for example, Quakers).  

In the early church, the eucharist was a meal, presided over by someone chosen from the congregation, or by the head of household, who might have been either a man or a woman. No priests.

The rituals that have developed during the history of the RCC and christianity in general,  were developed by men, and sometimes have become a bit ludicrous. When any small change from the GIRM becomes a matter for civil war in the RCC, the notion of  the importance of 'ritual" has gone too far, becoming an end in itself that is often even at odds with true prayer and true spirituality.

Comment: Calling Trump "Jacksonian" is idiotic.  Yes, Jackson was the first national politician to mobilize a non-moneyed constituency.  But when Jackson became president in 1829, he was not only a famous military hero.  He had also served in both houses of Congress and as military governor of the Florida territory.  He knew well, and was known by, all of the prominent political figures of his day.  And, in office, Jackson displayed a deep grasp of the Constitution and a determination to defend it against the growing possibility of secession.

None of this, of course, is true of Trump, who never served in the armed forces, never served in (or even ran for) public office, and apparently doesn't even pay income taxes.  Trump has never shown the slightest interest in the Constitution.  He has always been a political groupie, hanging around conventions for whatever scraps of attention he could pick up and engaging in scams like the Birther Lie.  He is no more like Jackson than Sarah Palin is.

Comment: And to continue on my point about the data used to show the CO2 lag, CO2 has been showed consistently to be the contributing factor behind the Greenhouse Effect. There's no way you are such a skeptic and non-believer to not believe the Greenhouse Effect does not exist. So with that, throughout history (from scientific data), CO2 ppm in the atmosphere never exceeded 300 ppm. NEVER. There were natural changes in the climate and the natural world flowed with itself, different events causing different warming and cooling trends. However, since man and industrialization came along we have not only exceeded 300ppm, we skyrocketed CO2 concentration to above 400ppm in a timeframe unprecedented by any increase in history. Such brain changes, and some experts call it "damage," may be permanent.

Comment: I'll try to refresh your memory.   I got this from the Huffington Post. 
1. On election night, several television networks called Florida for George W. Bush, clinching the electoral college — although Gore would end up winning about 500,000 more votes. Gore called Bush to concede.
2. Then the networks uncalled Florida — and Gore unconceded, realizing that he was ahead in the popular vote and if he ended up winning Florida he would have won the election. The election was literally too close to call.
3. A legally mandated recount began.
4. Bush (not Gore) sued to stop recounts in some counties.
5. Gore sued to extend deadlines for recounts.
6. The Florida Supreme Court ordered a more extensive recount. Bush (not Gore) appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court.
7. The U.S. Supreme Court stopped the recount.
8. Gore conceded.
Bush v. Gore would resonate, in any case, because the Court prevented Florida from determining, as best it could, whether Gore or Bush really won.

There is a curfew for children 16 and under.  If the police see them out after curfew, stop them and pat them down for police safety. Where this becomes politically divided is when Republicans want strict enforcement and accountability and Democrats want to treat the reason for these kids being out there.  My opinion is you can do both. Arrest them and then teach them that there is no future or tolerance for that kind of action.

Comment: My worst outdoor mishap was also a bicycle crash.  I was bicycling from Ouagadougou to Kongoussi (Burkina Faso), and was on a rough dirt single track trail on my touring bike complete with loaded panniers. I hit a bump that bounced the front panniers off of the rack and into the front tire causing the bicycle, but alas not myself, to come to an abrupt stop.  I endoed over the bars and landed on my face and shoulders.  My feet were clipped in to the pedals, so the loaded bike then came down on my back and head. I was bleeding from several gashes and slightly stunned, but at least 10 miles from anywhere, so I had to press on.  Fortunately the bike had no serious damage, and I eventually stopped bleeding when I became sufficiently dehydrated in the 110 degree heat.  I made it to Kongoussi eventually, where I was able to buy bottled water and rehydrate.  I later learned that Kongoussi means "don't sleep here" in the local language, but the night I spent camping there is another story.

Comment: I agree with you regarding science, and I've made it fully clear that I base my own opinions on scientific findings.  However, my education is in psychology, and prior to Freud the richest source for human psychology is in the world's non-fringe religious texts.   I'm no fundamentalist by any stretch, but I do respect truth wherever I find it.  I don't believe that all our ancestors prior to the 20th century were morons without any insight into human beings.  On the contrary, some of the most profound psychology I have ever found has been in religious texts, including the Bhagavad Gita, the Tao, and in Buddhism.  I did my senior research project on the subject.

I don't write to convince people of anything or to, in essence, get my way or change the world.  I write the truth as I see it, because truth is good enough on its own.

Comment: Although I have been a supporter of Inclusionary Zoning I cannot support SB 1533 unless it includes the following amendment:

Means Tested Inclusionary Housing that qualifies as PUBLIC HOUSING, i.e. a class of housing defined as, Means Test (<=80%MFI) + Government Subsidy (any government any type) + rental agreement, is not allowed in any neighborhood that already contains 15% or more PUBLIC HOUSING clients.

The housing policy of the city of Portland - Targeted, UNLIMITED Neighborhood Concentration of PUBLIC HOUSING - allows it to load any neighborhood of its choosing with up to 100% PUBLIC HOUSING clients. This clearly violates the Fair Housing Act of 1968 as recently reaffirmed by the United States Supreme Court. As currently written, SB 1533 could inadvertently or intentionally exacerbate Portland’s disregard for the federal goal of more Equitable Distribution of Public Housing.

Richard Ellmyer
North Portland

Comment: It's the right decision.  The whole point of the Establishment Clause was to stop the State from forcing people to participate in a certain religion.  That doesn't mean that the State is not permitted to provide financial support to any religion, nor does it mean that the State has to treat all religions the same.  It's about the government allowing people to freely practice the religion of their choice.

This "separation of church and state" nonsense should never have been used as legal reasoning in any of the Court's decisions.  The phrase carries no legal weight.

Comment: The "big dog" takes the bone from the smaller dog.  Dominant males use elaborate rituals to chase away lesser males and, thereby, achieve control of the breeding pool.....usually without actual battle.....simple bullying is adequate.  In the canine world if a bitch has too many pups, the stronger ones force the weaker ones away from the teats and they starve.  How many examples do you need?  In fact, we homo sapiens are virtually alone in our caring for the weaker members of our society.  It's ocassionally seen in other animals, but it's a rarity.  

Among humans there have likely always been bullies.  We all remember some from our own "school days."  Are there more today are are they just more "open" about it?  I'm not sure.  I do know that we've elected a President who is as great a bully as any man I've ever seen.  Frankly, I don't think that speaks well for our society or bodes well for our future.  Gary Crum

Comment: The only time you can change your oil too often is during the break-in period -- should leave it in for about the first  1500 km, but change very soon after that mark.  I'm surprised Lou didn't mention all of the variables.  If you drive a lot in extreme temperatures (6 months of the year in southern and eastern Ontario), or in dusty conditions, or do a lot of short trips, you should do it more often than the manufacturer recommends.  This means pretty much all of us.

Even if you don't like doing it yourself, it's cheap insurance.  A hundred bucks covers a full synth change with filter for most cars.  If you don't mind getting your hands dirty, it's only about forty.

I had a new VW back when they still did free maintenance for the first two years -- and the dealer strongly recommended that I get "supplemental" oil changes, which weren't covered.  I agreed with them.

Comment: "Trump encourages Russia to spy on Clinton"

No.

1. If Russia is not already spying on the secretary of state of their largest geopolitical rival, then they are the stupidest superpower in world history. They don't need Trump's "encouragement."

2. Trump is not "encouraging" Russia to hack into Clinton's email server. Trump is (correctly) noting that **they have almost certainly already hacked it** and is encouraging Russia to release what they found.

3. Clinton's lawyers and aides deleted almost 30,000 emails -- and wiped their hard drives -- before turning the rest over to investigators. They claimed that these 30,000 were not work-related. However, FBI investigators were able to recover some of the 30,000, and discovered that, yes, some of them were in fact work-related. 

4. So that is what Trump is saying: Hopefully, Russia will produce what Clinton's team deleted.

5. I despise Trump. For the record.

Comment: ALERT ALTERNATIVE - sad that Chaput steals this title from an excellent book of my adolescence - Stranger in a Strange Land.  Advise reading this Heinlen novel and not wasting time with Chaput's Napa Valley propaganda:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stranger_in_a_Strange_Land

Stranger in a Strange Land is a 1961 science fiction novel by American author Robert A. Heinlein. It tells the story of Valentine Michael Smith, a human who comes to Earth in early adulthood after being born on the planet Mars and raised by Martians. The novel explores his interaction with—and eventual transformation of—Terran culture. In 2012, the US Library of Congress named it one of 88 "Books that Shaped America".

The title "Stranger in a Strange Land" is an allusion to the phrase in Exodus 2:22

Comment: In order to critically examine Canada's health care system, the general Canadian public needs to first disabuse itself of two fallacies; 
1. Canada's health care is free; and
2. Canada's health care is among the best in the first World.

In fact, neither is true. One critic of Canada's health care system has stated to the effect: Canada has a Chevrolet system at Cadillac prices. 

Like many Canadians, I've paid at least tens of thousands (perhaps hundreds of thousands) of dollars in taxes during my life time toward health care expenditures, and probably used less than $5,000 worth of  medical services. This being said, I'm in favour of universal, public health care (especially for children and the elderly), believing that the overall health of the society is a general good. Still, it's time to look more critically at what should and shouldn't be covered. Otherwise, health care spending will consume ever larger portions of tax dollars, at the expense of other public needs in Canada.

Comment: 1.The Canadian gov't has committed to reducing ghg emissions in Canada to 30% below 2005 levels by 2030. The federal gov't will raise carbon taxes to 50 dollars a tonne by 2022. That will cost the average household about $1200 per year.
2. That target is 200 megatons  below our 2017 emissions and could be as much as 350 megatons if our economy grows at a steady rate till 2030. The gov't admits those taxes are not nearly enough. 
3. There are 500 coal fired plants being built in China, Asia, and Africa in 2017. Each plant produces 3.5 megatons of co2 emissions each year. A further 1100 plants are on the books. That is 42 per month. 
Do the math. The efforts of Canadians for the next 13 years, IF and that's a big if, at much higher carbon taxes than $50 a tonne, reach that target ..Six Weeks From Today, Asian coal emissions will have erased that sacrifice. Our carbon taxes and co2 emissions target are pointless, a gesture and very expensive symbolism. (And coal is just one fossil fuel.)

The court would be free to reinterpret the "living constitution" to mean whatever they want it to mean, thus they could invalidate any law that Congress might pass or any interpretation of law that the Executive might enact. The Judicial branch would thus become the defacto power of government in the United States, a five person board of Ayatollahs. Conservatives, conversely, may not make individual decisions a liberal would like, but maintain a Constitution whereby the rules stay the same. This stability is the basis of a stable and strong country. But even this is not the case here. Garland merely reestablishes the balance of the court, 4 liberals, 4 conservative, and a socially liberal but sometimes conservative Kennedy.

Comment: The only grounds on which the evidence could be deemed admissible is if doing so was less harmful to the administration of justice than excluding it. The Supreme Court ruled it wasn't admissible.

"If, as the Crown says, the situation was not serious enough to arrest and apply for a warrant, then it cannot have been serious enough to intrude into a private residence without a warrant." - Supreme Court of Canada

I sympathize with the actions of the police in the circumstances, however they handled the matter incorrectly from a legal standpoint. Beyond the smell of marijuana, there was no evidence of a crime. The initiator of the 911 call said she simply had an accident, and the owner of the apartment was cooperative. Again, with the benefit of hindsight, had the police used a different tactic the conviction would've stood.

Comment: Omakase is a chef's choice dinner available at most sushi spots that usually means the freshest or most interesting items of the day, while kaiseki is more formal, haute-cuisine prix-fixe fare.  A sunomono is basically lightly vinegared salad, often with cucumbers. And dashi is the base of most Japanese soup, often made using kelp. Didn't mean to alienate anybody with the terms, it's always a balancing act between over- and underexplaining.

For the record,  I don't want every restaurant to be what Fukami is; the full experience is expensive enough to make it a special occasion spot for 90% of Portland, me very much included. But If you love truly great nigiri, it's worth saving up for and great to have in the city. If not, then maybe not. A la carte--which still shows up on their website as an option--you can get out happy with five fish apiece and two rolls at $30 apiece. Not dirt-cheap, but that's maybe the price of a drunk night at Fire on the Mountain.

Comment: This is all good, but somewhat troubling in that it appears to be already "behind the curve", i.e.: "Preparing for the “gig” economy in which many Canadians are self-employed and earn a living through contracts."  Don't look now, but we're already there.  Back in the early '80s (when I quit my job of 10 years and contracted to the company and many others--in the employer's case, a 2-day-a-week "gig") it was pretty revolutionary.  But that was close to forty years ago!  

So, this isn't so much "forward-thinking" as it is "catch up." Given that breath-taking lack of foresight, it makes me suspect that the planners and thinkers haven't yet figured out what the unintended consequences of raising the retirement age.  If not, then sound the alarm...

Comment: I have no problem with a person expressing their opinion, right or wrong. We live in a society that is governed by rules and regulations, supposedly for the good of all, not just a few. Some of those rules even trump individual rights at times. Unfettered social action is, at its heart, social anarchy. We lock people up for committing crimes against individuals they may feel is perfectly okay - even their duty - to commit. Yet, when they commit them it is considered a harm to society. That's why you don't get to decide who gets prosecuted; the state, supposedly representing all citizens, does.

Comment: We must agree to disagree on this.  I agree that by country, correlation of gun ownership and suicide rate does not match.  Japan's culture is very different than our own, for example.  Suicide can be a matter of honor there.  But by state in the U.S., the correlation is very high, because in this culture, suicide is not seen as honorable, and most suicide attempts are a cry for help.  Problem is, having a gun usually makes the first attempt lethal.  Or in this particular case, lethal to an innocent bystander.
And then there is the killer toddler problem.
I agree, I'm much more likely to be killed by some idiot texting while driving than by a random gun nut, but that does not mean that I accept that we have to have all these innocent people die because of our sick gun culture.  We need to educate people that having a gun in the home is a significant risk, and if you choose to risk it, you need to take classes to understand how to handle guns.
Good evening.

Comment: Wente certainly knows little about coding, and I doubt she knows much about the math she tries to uphold.

Math is not really about counting and numbers, but rather about logic and abstraction, often but not exclusively using numbers as the symbolic layer.  Solving math problems is no more and no less than an exercise in thinking straight.

Coding is also about logic and abstraction, using the keywords of the programming language as the symbolic layer.

In other words, coding -- all of computer science, really -- is a form of mathematics, pure or applied.

And coding is just as much as traditional school math an exercise in thinking straight.

The majority of patients who are seen at ANMC or SEARHCC are funded via Native Health Care funds AND at the same time through Medicaid funds. 

Since the Native Health Care organizations operate extensively in each region of the state, they have set the market rate and because they hare effectively circumventing cost controls, they have set it quite high.

Comment: Well, I've been out of college for a long time, but hydrogen used to be an element, not an "energy storage system", whatever that means. An element that, when combined with oxygen, produces water and gives off: Energy!

Hydrogen, as many of us learned in high school, is easily produced by energizing water with electricity. It can then be made to surrender that energy by combining it with oxygen. Several car companies are already making hydrogen-fueled cars. The trick for success will be to produce both economical and durable fuel cells, and compact and economical storage devices. My point was that, with sufficient investment in research, we could likely achieve these objectives. Maybe by not flushing away trillions of dollars, and sacrificing the lives or health of hundreds of thousands of soldiers in stupid and futile wars, we could be there by now. It was once impossible to split the atom, too.

Cheap hydrogen storage would be a game-changer for personal solar and wind generation.

Comment: Hi, Doc.  Two recent foreign purchase surveys were done by the BC government since mid-summer, each covering about 2 weeks of real estate transactions.  One: July/Aug before tax Implementation, another in the fall.  Both indicated that, overall, the foreign purchase component was less than I2% of the deals.  Even 15% would have qualified as "minor" in my mind.  And these includes EVERY conceivable type of foreigner, including Americans (who rank as Canada's 5th largest immigrant cohort. Source: stats can)

So, this begs a number of questions: 
1. Who was involved in all non-foreigner deals?  Probable ans: obviously a combination of established local renters and owners and Canadian in-migration.

2 does the total value of these deals equal or surpass that "flood of overseas billions"?  Probable ans, based on about 90% of all deals, yes.  

3. Re: pricing out local workers.  Yup...many are priced out (see #1) 

4. Other causes? Lack of available land and high demand by domestic buyers.

Comment: Euthanasia is a very difficult matter.  When absolutely forbidden, it sentences some to horrible, cruel and inhumane pain and suffering; but when the laws allowing it are too wide, allowing people to kill themselves or even having doctors do it for them for reasons that are not eminent death, there are a whole lot of very difficult problems opened up.  What of the children and grandchildren that are deprived of the presence of a family member that would and could have lived for many years?  For this reason I think the state of Montana may have a better idea by decriminalizing it but not allowing rules for physicians to act as Gods.  I do not think that a doctor himself should ever push the medicine that kills, but not to allow a terminally ill patient to take a lethal dose is also extremely cruel and adds to suffering, not palliation of a patients pain and suffering.  The Oregon law is fairly good as the numbers of people remain small. Medical opinion involved butnot doctor termination

Comment: Mr. Anderson: I believe that you and Ihave been around long enough to remember the 1960s, when the state of Alaska had little money. As I review our oil period, I remember those years and the rush to cement a deal at the time of the North Slope discovery. Those few years forever determined the outcome of this strange deal between producers and the state of Alaska. We can't undo that time period.

Things are different now. The oil embargo of the 1970s and the accompanying price hike brought production to places where it had not been before: those places (like Alaska), now feed their populations with the profits from oil; they ca't stop producing. This is one of the main factors the market is realizing.

Even if we get short run increases in income from restructuring taxes, in the long run, we will still run short. In my view we need to learn to live within our means. When people begin paying a tax, waste will become a visible issue. We are in for many changes in our old age, I"m afraid.

Comment: Employees using paychecks, which become their property when issued, to buy pork or porn is a different matter than an employer being required to buy insurance that covers medications, devices or procedures that the employer finds to be against his moral or religious convictions. In effect the employer is buying the birth control pills or IUD through the mechanism of paying premiums to a third party, not the employee, on an insurance policy that will be used to directly purchase those items. 

Employers were told by administrative directive that they have to purchase something that pays for meds or devices that they find objectionable. It is not in the ACA; therefore changing the directive is within the bounds of the law, by design. The lawsuits over this are similar to lawsuits on DACA - telling the executive branch they must do something no law says they have to do - a very odd thing to sue over.

Comment: You are badly misinformed.  The vote in Manitoba in 1990 was not a vote on the Meech Lake Accord. It was a vote to suspend the rules of the Legislature in order to cut short public hearings on the Accord and to expedite a vote on the Meech Lake resolution. To suspend the rules of the Legislature, the consent of every MLA is required. That is how Elijah Harper was able to defeat Meech Lake.  He postponed the holding of a vote on the resolution until the 3-year ratification deadline had expired.  Had a vote on the resolution been held, it would not have required the unanimous consent of members. A simple majority would have sufficed.

Comment: You are taking a very short term view. It is not necessary to dismiss management. Usually, by the time you become a senior manager, you are no more than fifteen years from retirement. If, for instance, the CRA followed a policy of allowing existing managers to remain in place and manage remotely but insisted that all replacements, including promotions, must move to Summerside, the   "remote manager" issue would be entirely solved within twenty years. 

Alternatively, managers could be constructively dismissed, paid severance, and replaced with people willing to live in Summerside if it was considered desirable to complete the move quickly. It's a question of economics, and not a show-stopper.

Comment: The Lancet editor got it wrong though - it is medical literature, not scientific literature which is the problem. The key difference between science and medicine is that medicine is all about curing illnesses whereas science is all about understanding. Of course, if you understand an illness you have a far better chance of curing it but this difference in focus is what leads to all the problems.

A medical researcher wants to find a cure so if they find that patients who take magic pill A get cured of disease B it's a huge success. However, without understanding how magic pill A cures disease B there is no science here. This focus on correlation rather than causation is what leads to the problems because a golden rule of science is that correlation does not imply causation.

Comment: The Minnedosa ethanol  plant is one of the largest emitters of greenhouse gas in Manitoba. The article suggests that we should increase the amount of ethanol currently mandated as an environmental gasoline additive. 

A fatal Lac Magantic type rail tanker fire in the US was what started the implementation of the new design for a new type of rail tanker. The train's cargo was ethanol. Lets use Canadian rail to haul more ethanol to fuel blending plants. (Pipelines can no longer be built in Canada.)

I am not aware of any bio-diesel produced in Canada that will can be used in a diesel engine in cold weather. A company in Finland has built two specialized refineries that make a winter grade additive to make biodiesel. They typically use palm oil as the raw ingredient. 

BC was the first Canadian province to mandate the reduction of carbon in motor fuels. They quickly backed off their plan when they discovered that it doesn't work on a Canadian winter.

Comment: Recent era tradition for majority governments in Canada is to prorogue parliament roughly halfway through a 4-year mandate in order to start a second session with a fresh throne speech.

The obvious time to do this for the Trudeau Liberals would be after the summer break, likely Sept. 18th, the first day that the House sits.  What that would mean is that any legislation that has not yet received royal asset by the June 23rd, the last day before the summer break, would die on the floor.

Obviously the Liberals are not required to prorogue parliament at that time and they could certainly wait until after the Christmas break to start a new session, but either way they are running short on time if they follow recent-era tradition.

Comment: The current immigration policy is designed to double Canada's population well before the end of the century.  It is still 1910 in Ottawa.  Social programs and fiscal balance are not dependent on the size or growth rate of the population but on the health of the economy and the quality of jobs.

The quality of jobs has been falling in this country which means that tax revenues go down and social support increases.  This defines a structural deficit.  Going forward with the simple growth model, leaving all considerations of per capita resource declines aside, increasing deficits and declining services will continue.

Growth forever is clearly not an option.  Only a stable and healthy economy can support a progressive society.

Cheers,
John Meyer

Comment: I don't know, we're talking possibilities. I'm not an attorney. But, typically, laws that apply to taverns stress they are negligent if they do not ask for proof of age (when appropriate), if they serve obviously inebriated customers (or customers that could be reasonably assumed to be so, i.e. have been served 3 drinks w/in one hour period), or if they serve after closing hours.
I am attempting to disagree with the notion that taverns bear no responsibility. Knowing what we know about alcoholism, and individual responsibility in general, it is unreasonable to expect customers to make responsible decisions--- a sober and law-abiding server is a better bet. Those who profit bear responsibility for the outcomes of their actions. It isn't either/or but rather both customer and tavern owner bearing responsibility.

Comment: The ban that the author seeks to have applied nationwide is not actually attempting any sort of regulation on the "breeding" side of things.    Which is why there is little attempt to distinguish breeders.

The ban is a ban of sales of pets at pet stores.     With the feeling that the lack of this retail outlet will then kill the market that supports puppy mills, etc.

That would not make it illegal to sell a newly bred pet anywhere.  It would just kill the "impulse buy" factor of seeing an adorable little face, and taking it home without thinking.      You could still go to a breeder and get a pet.   

But if you went to the breeder, you'd have to find them, and do research. You'd have to have thought through being a pet owner.  And if you went to a breeder and found wildly inhumane conditions, you probably would not do business with them, and may report them.

And if you bought from a reputable breeder, they might make sure you knew what you were getting into.

Comment: Without shame, there can be no progress. For it is shame and the sense of injustice and the failure to do right that we see that a different decision must be made in the future.

The kind of boisterous flag-waving history promoted by Prof Granastein tends to be that of the Establishment. It's not real history. It doesn't include the dissenting voices or the inconvenient facts behind the scenes.

Official History may be written by the Victors, but we know that's not what happened. Canada has a 1000 stories to it that aren't WASP. We can celebrate Josiah Henson while feeling shame at the treatment of Viola Desmond.

Comment: If you have been paying CPP for 38 years then you VASTLY underpaid for your own benefits through the first 15 to 20 of those years.

CPP rates were kept at levels FAR below what was required throughout the 1970's, 1980's and into the 1990's.  The whole system was based around the demographic trends seen during the baby boom which was already over when CPP was first introduced.  As a result it was setup as a Ponzi scheme that was doomed to failure.

It wasn't until the mid 1990's that CPP was completely reformed, with much higher contribution rates, that people began not only paying for their own CPP, but also covering off the massive shortfall left for the first 30 years that CPP existed.  We still have another 15 to 20 years to go to pay off that deficit, after which the system will be more or less equitable.

Comment: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patriotism
Patriotism is an emotional attachment to a nation which an individual recognizes as their homeland. This attachment, also known as national feeling or national pride, can be viewed in terms of different features relating to one's own nation, including ethnic, cultural, political or historical aspects. It encompasses a set of concepts closely related to those of nationalism. An excess of patriotism in the defense of a nation is called chauvinism.

Chauvinism: exaggerated or aggressive patriotism: excessive or prejudiced loyalty or support for one's own cause, group, or gender

Comment: "What caused the crash remains a mystery. So is whether there is any connection between the clam crash and recent die-offs of sea stars, otters and murres in Kachemak Bay."

No doubt that multiple causes are in play but I know for a fact that the explosion of the otter population plays a large part in the matter. It's hard to find a butter over 3" in Kachemak Bay these days, but one can find a war zone of 'bomb craters' where they have been dug up by otters. Comment: Its unfortunate folks make claims based on self serving marketing messages.  The UBC project is a concrete core structure not a CLT project.  Almost all CLT projects need some form of subsidy, grant or award to be first cost competitive.  The real discussion and opportunity should be to design and construct buildings to get the most out of the materials used.  The best buildings and outcomes are a collaboration of materials.  It is well documented the true cost of ownership (85-90%) is in the operational or service life of the building in energy consumption and costs, maintenance, insurance against fire and other considerations, not in the upfront construction costs.   Reducing these emissions and costs is where the greatest contribution to sustainability and emission reductions are gained.   CLT is not approved by building, fire or seismic codes.  

Why is concrete, steel and masonry used in high impact transportation and infrastructure projects.... Durability, resiliency, strength.

Comment: I don't know which jury the author is referring to but it's not out. The commercial aviation industry has known for some time the effects of prolonged on duty hours for all crew, but particularly for cockpit crew.

Comment: The Endangered Species Act is perhaps the most effective tool available for curtailing or halting resource development.  Having been unsuccessful in previous attempts to convince the USFWS to list the Alexander Archipelago wolf, the Queen Charlotte Goshawk, the marbled murrelet and several other species in Southeast Alaska, the Center for Biological Diversity and its co-petitioners now are attempting to have the yellow cedar listed.  While there are many reasons that the timber industry in Southeast Alaska has declined to its current low level of productivity - particularly on Tongass National Forest lands - listing the yellow cedar could finally bring it to an end.  If yellow cedar is listed under the ESA, timber harvest on state and private corporation lands will be affected along with national forest lands.

Comment: The US Fed targets the PCEPI, whose annual inflation rate went from  1.00% in August to 1.25% in September. The Bank of Canada targets the CPI, whose annual inflation rate went from 1.1% in August to 1.3% in September to 1.5% in October. 
If one looks instead at core inflation the PCEPILFE annual inflation rate was 1.78% in September, unchanged from August. Quite unconscionably the Bank of Canada has no mandated core inflation measure we can look at following the dysfunctional renewal of its inflation control agreement . It still hasn’t published the new measures that will be replacing the superior CPIX measure. However, the annual CPIX inflation rate was 1.8% in August, 1.8% in September and 1.7% in October. So from the inflation data, there seems no reason to believe that the US and Canadian economies are on quite different paths, and that the Bank of Canada can comfortably ignore the expected increase in the US federal funds rate later this month, or any subsequent increase in 2017.

Comment: Your argument is better than most, GS, but it still has fatal shortcomings.

TWU doesn't deny entry to ANYONE. Everyone is welcome, regardless of their religion, sexual orientation, etc. Those who enter voluntarily agree to abide by certain rules. LSUC, however, DOES deny entry to certain people: those who got their law degrees at Trinity Western.

I can certainly accept that LSUC may establish rules for its membership, just as TWU does. For example, LSUC could state explicitly that their members must offer professional services to anyone regardless of the sexual orientation. Voila! Problem solved, no? 

However that's not the approach LSUC has taken. Rather, it seeks to exert influence over a religious institution by denying entry to those who are or were members of it.

Comment: Something Anderson consistently neglects to mention is that the route of the pipeline has not been approved by the NEB. Additionally, the route approval process has been delayed over a month by the company's mismanagement of its responsibilities in the process. The period for written statements of opposition runs now till July (some variation depending on what segment of the route one is dealing with), and after that will come public hearings. After that the NEB will decide whether to approve the route or not, segment by segment. At this stage it's looking likely that some segments of the route will be rejected. They might be able to start construction in the Fall if they're willing to gamble on an incomplete route. If some segments of the route go back to square one, completion will be a long way off. It would be interesting to know how many investors were unaware of this.

Comment: Free speech has nothing to do with a newspaper printing (or not printing) what you have to say.  The concept of free speech is between citizen and her government, where the government is not allowed to abrogate the citizen's right to say what she wants (at least within the limits provided by the Charter of Rights and Freedoms).  A newspaper, being a private entity, can publish whatever or whomever it wants.  It has no obligation to publish (or refrain from publishing) anything.

Comment: Part human nature but more human error in handling technology, I think. Comment: Glad you all could make it up. I have a tale to tell.  I was working as s surveyor and geologist in what  I believe to be the first party over the Atagan pass  on foot.  We were let off from the helicopter at the base of the ugly grade (before there was a grade or road) and worked our way up for the rest of the day.  At the end of the day, the helicopter came to find us but was working 2,000 feet below us.  ( with the wisdom of the time, our radios could not talk to the helicopter, or camp, go figure)  A thin shaft of sunlight came through and I was able to catch the helicopter with my signal mirror and we went home warm and safe.  Point: The mirrors never lose their charge and never go off channel.  If the sun is there, they are there.  they have helped me out no less than seven times, some far more important than the above. Good luck, enjoy, try it again in the spring when the flyway is open.

Comment: Mr. Plant is, as noted, a lawyer and a former Attorney-General (he was NOT a good Attorney-General, but that's beside the point). He should have the applicable laws and Rules memorized. The requirement that the Speaker must be a MLA is found in s. 37 of the BC Constitution Act, which despite its name is ordinary legislation that can be amended in the ordinary fashion.

The new government can solve the Speaker problem very simply by amending s. 37 to remove the requirement for the Speaker to be a MLA. A non-member Speaker, who would be an officer of the Legislature, would give the NDP/Green alliance a one vote majority.

Comment: Please don't go all self-righteous on this. I have no hesitation in judging slavery to be an evil thing. But that doesn't mean that every monument erected in the era, or afterwards depicting an individual from that era, is evil as well. It's not. It's an expression of a collective sentiment in the day. 

By reading the surviving record, one can get a feel for what prominent people may have thought at the time. But we have no idea what each person who democratically went along thought of it. If we remove that statue, we censor that collective expression of free speech. And we do so not because that expression is hate speech, as a mere statue can never be. We do it self-righteously, to condemn what we, in ignorance of all that was involved, interpret as a negative thing.

The analogy to free expression today is that we should suppress the speech of an entire group, because we disapprove of the comments of some members of that group.

Comment: “Everyone can see what you put on the internet anyway.” Not really. In the case of Facebook, many of us have privacy settings that limit posts to viewing by “friends.” We have a reasonable expectation of privacy, that members of that group are not going to share our comments and photos with the masses without asking in advance. If we post to the “wall” of someone else, it’s fair to believe the audience is limited to that person’s “friends.” It is generally a violation of journalistic ethics to publish something that was intended for a limited audience or otherwise “off the record,” whether it’s overheard from a nearby table in the restaurant or “overheard” from a Facebook post. Elected officials and other public figures (I don't believe Gwendolyn Iris is one), of course, have to meet higher standards to be “off the record.”

Comment: If, as you say, 11% of Americans have no health coverage and a large number find paying for care to be a difficult burden, would you be opposed to politicians and others focusing on solving those problems and not turning the entire health system on its ear for the vast majority of Americans?  When I worked in Health Care Management for the VA, we knew that we had to carefully plan for transferring patients from an older nursing home to a newer structure.  A certain number of patients will simply die, when their caregivers or environments change, unless extreme care is taken.  Many would lose their doctor under Single Payer.

As for quality, in Single Payer UK, an audit by the NHS found that their breast cancer patients had a 79% survival rate versus 97% for American women.  Without the profit motive, the drug that gave US women about a 25% better chance of survival would not have been developed.  I guess the death of others is a risk you are willing to take, to get your way.

Comment: >But, how do you measure and make the distinction between man made and natural phenomena?
I bet you think you're being rational and not just quoting another completely idiotic piece of denialist propaganda.
It's actually ridiculously easy to measure the impact of man-made activity - we've been doing it for decades. You see all carbon are not created equal. The carbon from fossil fuels have a particular mixture of isotopes you don't find in any other source (and nothing except humans burn fossil fuels). The increased CO2 in the atmosphere - consists entirely of carbon that could ONLY have come from fossil fuels - volcanic CO2 for example has a a completely different isotopic distribution.
We CAN tell where it came from. We can tell how much came from where.
Volcanoes are the only other significant source of CO2. The USGS (world's greatest volcano experts) published a paper with the numbers. Total volcanic CO2 per annum 0.025% of what coal plants ALONE add.

Comment: News is part of the profit line on TV stations.  They always have been.  Recouping the costs of a news department was the advertising sold during the broadcasts.  Now, that revenue source is significantly reduced with the onslaught of cable news running on a 24/7 cycle.  Add to that, the internet and the viewership is diminished even more.

That being said, it may appear to the ardent and uptight folks at Civil Beat that they can criticize the rest of the journalists in town, but for a bunch of mainland folks who beg for donations to survive, they should be the last to acknowledge the radical changes the news business has had in the last two decades.  Loss of major news paper, the consolidation of THREE TV news departments, and further  layoffs at our sole remaining newspaper should be up there on their list of daily concerns.

So when they close the UH School of Communications for losing too much money, I hope to see Mr. Oppegaard in Waikiki hawking tours to stay in Hawaii!

Comment: How Anyone Can Invest Their Way to Early Retirement:

-Don't go into debt for your education
-Get a job, preferably one in the public service with an indexed pension
-Once you have a well paying job, buy a reasonably priced house/condo - this is the only acceptable debt because real estate is an appreciating asset
-Buy a secondhand vehicle if you need one - don't finance it
-Take at least 10% of your paycheque and invest it prudently - then don't touch it
-As your income increases over the years, spend below your means
-Pay off your mortgage as soon as possible
-Put those savings into your RRSP

Voila, freedom 55 or perhaps earlier. Simple

Comment: While the author is right that racism persists throughout the white South African community (just scroll through the comments here), am not so convinced of his opinion that the "desperation" of middle class black parents is fueled solely by feelings of cultural inferiority.

The author does a disservice to the good points he makes regarding the insidious influence of feelings of cultural superiority/inferiority by ignoring the real issue driving parental “desperation” in South Africa.

Comment: The overriding issue here is the extent to which social services (including health care) should or can address all instances of high-risk behaviour. Herein, I do not see myself as being mean-spirited, because I did live in the tropics and/or subtropics for nearly a decade. During that time, I kept my vaccinations current and I made myself well-aware of the vectors for microbial and parasitic diseases. Consequently, I remained disease-free, and I made no claims on Canada's public health system in respect of tropical ailments. Is it too much to ask that others should emulate that sort of example? Certainly, failure to do so risks overburdening a system that is already straining to address home-grown ailments.

Comment: Lastly, carrying all of this debt is preventing Canadians from saving for retirement.  And this will only get worse as interest rates climb.  Most Canadians do not have defined pensions. I know one person who is an owner and who plans to fund his retirement by selling his home in 10 years and move abroad where housing is way cheaper.  Of all the other home owners I know maybe 10%  are planning to sell and are willing to move out of the city, but are all concerned that they'll be away from their kids and grandkids.  And are we to suppose that the rest of the owners are going to sell their homes and manage to live off the $500,000 difference they make in the downsize but stay in the city?

Comment: I recently had a double heart valve replacement. It was deemed elective because it was caused by a slow calcium build up and not an emergency. Comment: David Lewis - Transportation money cannot be used for health care & most village health care centers are funded by BIA/Native Corporation funds any way. King Cove has a health center, but like most village health centers, it can't handle anything critical. Unless you want to staff these village clinics full-time with specialists, you're not getting rid of the need for med evacs. The difference between King Cove & many other villages is that it is frequently beset by weather that prevents aircraft from being able to safely use its airfield.

The questions you ask would be answered during the DOT process of designing the road. It would likely be something similar to the Tanana Road, which 4WDs can navigate in the winter. It was built with State funds, so didn't have to meet federal highway standards, so cost about $14 million. The King Cove road is less than one-tenth the length, so should cost much less. There is also already some old road in place that could be part of the project.

Comment: Medicare as presently set up only handles a small segment of the market...around 15%:

http://www.kff.org/other/state-indicator/total-population/?currentTimeframe=0&sortModel=%7B%22colId%22:%22Location%22,%22sort%22:%22asc%22%7D

The coverage and costs will not be the same if the entire market is under that one umbrella.  Again, those providers participating in Medicare programs offload their marginalized profits to the private side of the market.

I'm not saying it won't work.  All I'm saying is before we sign on the dotted line, we fully understand the costs, where the money comes from, and how it affects service.  That's all.  Simply saying, "it'll be better" is unsubstantiated because Medicare in this hybrid market is not the same as Medicare in a single payer market.

Comment: As a employer I will be increasing the price of my products, as with previous minimum wage increase. The price increases are not the result of my business paying minimum wage to employees. Its the result of price increases coming from my suppliers who do employ minimum wage workers.

In the end the cost of all goods and services will rise. That rise is actually greater than someone like yourself could comprehend.

One of my products requires components from six suppliers, all use minimum wage workers meaning each component will increase in price. I must factor in all six price increases to my finished product price. My distributors who also employ minimum wage workers will also increase the price of my product.

When that minimum wage worker now goes to buy my product it will cost them roughly 25% more. Remember they only received a 15% wage increase, making them 10% worst off.

The rich get richer and the poor just keep on getting poorer. But lets believe some study instead.

Comment: Toronto and Vancouver a not the same.  Vancouver prices are soaring because the city is surrounded by mountains which significantly restrict the amount of land available.
Toronto, on the other hand, has it man-made barrier to access to land - the Green Belt.   Victor Doyle (see article last week), try to convince us that the Green Belt is not affecting prices, common sense and unbiased analysis proves otherwise.  I do not support scrapping the Green Belt, but only recognize that it does have an impact.
Low interest rates were the instigator of soaring housing prices in Toronto.  In a well functioning market, new houses would have been build to satisfy this demand and there would have been a modest increase in real prices.
But, we don't have a well functioning market.  We have a highly regulated market where the time from development proposal to actual building of homes can take 10 years.  Hence, the modest increase in demand led to soaring prices as serious shortages of houses emerged.

Comment: You are spot on.  I worked at HIHS many years ago and the vast majority of the animals put down were feral cats. I used to work with Advocats back then (to try to improve relationships with the animal welfare groups, doesn't seem like they've quite kept up with that) and I was dismayed to see how many people will simply drive out to Old A's or the Kea'au transfer station and dump their cats. I'm now that person who will really ruin a conversation the minute someone brings up how they plan to breed their animals or how their dog just had puppies and now they are giving away un-neutered pups.  I think HIHS could do a lot better (esp at public relations), but I will tell you the problem rests firmly with people who don't spay and neuter.

Comment: The article does not focus on the real issue. Whoever has visited a recent trade fair with Chinese participants or follows their technical development, it gets really obvious. 

China can do high technology innovation by itsself and simply does not need covert operations anymore. China and Asia are starting to lead in all fields of engineering.

Like it or not. The only advantage for countries such as Canada and Germany are having is staying on top of the innovation front and invest heavily in education and research.  

During the past 20 years China for example has taken the lead in mobile phone technology / infrastructure, which was firm in European hands until 2005 and now they are starting the same in High Voltage Direct Current (HVDC) power transmission. This technology is the most complex technology in long distance power transmission worldwide, which also has Canada and Europe just still leading. A third example is battery storage for electric cars and the list goes on and on.

Comment: Properly understood, the liturgy is the sacrament of our conversion to God in Christ, which results in our being empowered to transform the world in the power of the Spirit. Prayer, praise, proclamation -- all play a role in the process of sacramental conversion, but when any of them is emphasized more than the others, our liturgies can fail to achieve their purpose and leave our congregations unchanged by the experience, which has long been the unfortunate norm in our parishes. Then, people gather out of obligation, or enjoyment of an aesthetic experience, or some similarly mundane motive.
I agree with Michael that preparation of our liturgies ("the work of the people") is essential, but I also agree with his implication that few of our liturgies are well prepared by the people who participate in them. In my view, I think Christianity's adoption of the mandatory sabbatical celebrations has resulted in our taking the liturgy for granted and our passive acceptance of an hourly ritual.

Comment: Trudeau and his team have never really defended NAFTA in these negotiations  as far as I can see. When you keep spouting figures about how we are the #1 foreign trade partner and so forth, you are promoting the US-Canada FTA, not NAFTA. Brian Mulroney wanted a NAFTA to avoid a hub-and-spoke arrangement where the US would be the hub with bilateral free trade agreements with other North American countries, which would be so many spokes. If Trudeau had been championing NAFTA he would have been repeating that argument wherever he would, although it does lose some of its force now that the US has engaged in free trade deals with countries in central America and the Caribbean without enlarging NAFTA.

Comment: "A plucky bull escaped from a slaughterhouse and led police on a wild chase through the streets on Tuesday only to die on its way to a shelter."
.
.    .     .     .     .
.
At first sight, the idea of a bull from New York on the loose seemed an irresistible opportunity for humour ... all that was missing was a china shop, and a reference to the White House.
.
Yet reading the story, it turns out to be about an undocumented fugitive nobly seeking freedom, and dying on the way to shelter ...
.
Yes, it is a metaphor for our times, nonetheless, but far more poignant than the one that might have been expected.

Comment: CHARLES HAS ANTI-WHITE BIAS... WOW
(1) The indigenous people of the interior and high North of Alaska had no concept of land ownership.  When fish runs in rivers changed, local people FOUGHT WARS over who it was who WON control the new fish run. 
(2) The indigenous people of the interior and high North of Alaska had no written language.  Oral histories alone were passed down from speakers to listeners ... and old people memories changed as conditions changed.
(3) The indigenous people of the interior and high North of Alaska had no government concept or legal system dividing property.  In fact, the frozen interior and high North of Alaska did not have local peoples who EVEN SURVIVED in the very cold, dark wind.  At least 3 different DNA groups lived prior in DEEP FREEZE ALASKA: they all died out earlier!  Today's Alaskan "FIRST PEOPLES" are actually at least the 4th GROUP in Alaska ... and present dwellers have no DNA relationship with today's Yupik-Athabascans-Haida-Tlingit, etc.

Comment: You can minimize the argument by saying it`s "only" 4000 slope workers.. but when you figure Alaska would get $80 million from those folks ALONE, (out of state workers who earn income here..) to help pay for schools and cops and roads.  
I`m glad YOU think $80 million bucks every year from oil workers etc is "insignificant".  
I would posit most of us think that`s a big chunk of money that will stay inside Alaska and not go to Texas.  
But well before an income tax, or giving away our kids PFD value forever like the Senate would do, we have to recover our "one third" share of the gross value of our oil lost with SB21.  
The unaudited padding of slope expenses needs to stop. I also agree with Alaskan oil attorney Robin Brena, that perhaps it`s time for another citizen's initiative, similar to the one repealing SB21, mandating recovery of what Governor Jay Hammond called "our one third share of the value of oil we own" as originally agreed to by the feds the state and the oil companies.

Comment: I have 260,000+ km on my '06 3 series. I purchased it slightly used in 2007 and used the dealership for service until the original factory warranty ran out. Then I found a shop in Toronto that specializes in BMWs and found them friendly, informative, and far far cheaper than dealership service.  My average service costs for the last 6 years are $1000/year. So don't buy that warranty and find a good shop instead.
